content: The Act titled "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" aims to promote the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels. It includes an amendment regarding coastwise transportation of passengers. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation. The act includes regulations for coastwise passenger transportation, specifying ownership requirements and vessel documentation criteria. An exception is made for cruise vessels under an 18-month demise charter to a US citizen or entity. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation, with regulations for coastwise passenger transportation. An exception is made for cruise vessels under an 18-month demise charter to a US citizen or entity. Cruise vessels can operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter termination with approval from the Secretary and compliance with specified terms. An exception is also provided for vessels not documented under chapter 121 of title 46, US Code, and at least 5 years old. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for the construction of a new cruise vessel in the US if the existing vessel is between 5 and 15 years old. The owner must also have a contract for a new vessel with at least 80% capacity. The authority to operate the vessel terminates 18 months after receiving a coastwise endorsement if construction on a new vessel has not begun. Definitions in this section include coastwise trade as transportation of a passenger between points in the United States, either directly or by way of a foreign port, and a cruise vessel as a vessel that is at least 10,000 gross tons with accommodations for at least 200 passengers. The term 'related person' refers to a holding company, subsidiary, affiliate, or association of a person, as well as an officer, director, or agent of the person or related entity. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow certain vessels to comply with specific regulations and receive a certificate of inspection. Vessels meeting certain criteria related to control verification, coastwise endorsement, and authorization for coastwise trade are eligible for this certification. SEC. 6 amends the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 by including passenger and cargo. SEC. 7 addresses permits for vessels entering national park units. The Secretary of the Interior has priority rules for vessel operation in National Park System units. First priority is for vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Second priority is for foreign-documented vessels already permitted. Third priority is for other vessels. The Secretary can revoke permits for foreign-documented vessels. The Secretary of the Interior can revoke permission for foreign-documented vessels operating in National Park System units if a US-documented vessel requests permission due to permit limits. However, this revocation cannot apply to individuals with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Those whose permits are revoked have the first right to a new permit when conditions change.
